questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is not included in the WHO definition of health?
questions.explanation:
According to the WHO, health is “a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being and 
not merely the absence of disease or infirmity”. In recent years, the definition has been modified to also include the ability to lead a “socially and 
economically productive life.”

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is the biomedical concept of disease based upon?

options.b: Combination of social, economic and political influences

questions.explanation:
The biomedical concept of disease is based on the germ theory of disease, which was postulated by 
Louis Pasteur. The germ theory of disease states that microorganisms known as pathogens or germs can lead to 
disease. It was criticized that it did not include environmental, social, psychological, and cultural 
determinants of health. The ecological concept of disease states that disease is the maladjustment of the human organism 
to the environment. The psychosocial concept of disease hypothesised that health is also influenced by social, 
psychological, cultural and economic factors as well. The holistic concept of disease includes all the above concepts to describe health. 33 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is a mortality indicator?
questions.explanation:
Life expectancy is a positive mortality indicator. A set of values that measure the rate of mortality or death is known as mortality indicators. Disability-adjusted life years (DALY), health adjusted life expectancy (HALE), and Sullivan’s Index 
are disability rates.

questions.question:
Question 4: An epidemiologist is tasked with measuring the overall health status of a community using a 
morbidity indicator. Which of the following indicators will she not use?

options.c: Number of days of restricted activity

questions.explanation:
Number of days of restricted activity is a disability indicator. Morbidity is defined as public health outcomes focusing on diseases, traumas, or injury. Morbidity 
indicators can be used to measure the overall health and extent of healthcare utilisation in a given 
population. Disability is defined as public health outcomes related to health conditions that include 
limitations in personal activities and societal participation. There are two types of disability 
indicators as follows: • Event type indicators- • Number of days of restricted activity • Bed disability days • Work loss days (or school loss days) within a specified period • Person type indicators- • Limitation of mobility: e.g confined to bed • Limitation of activity: e.g limitation to perform the basic activities of daily living such as eating 
and going to the toilet

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following indicators can be used to estimate the number of years a newborn 
would be expected to live in full health based on the current rates of ill health and mortality?
questions.explanation:
HALE (Health Adjusted Life Expectancy) is an indicator that can be used to estimate the number 
of years a newborn is expected to live in full health based on the current rates of ill health and 
mortality. HALE is calculated using the life expectancy at birth with an adjustment for time spent in poor 
health. It captures both fatal and non-fatal health outcomes of average levels of population health. 
It is also sensitive to changes over time or differences between countries in the distribution of 
health states. Sullivan's index is also known as disability-free life expectancy (DFLE) or active life expectancy. It 
is the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability if the current 
patterns of mortality and disability continue to apply. It doesn’t take into account premature 
death. As HALE includes not just disability but the larger definition of poor health, it is a better 
option with respect to the question. 34 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: While assessing the health needs of a community, an epidemiologist is tasked with estimating 
the burden of cholera in the area. Which of the following is the simplest measure he can use?
questions.explanation:
The proportional mortality rate is the simplest measure of estimating the burden of disease in the 
community. It signifies the proportion of all deaths that can be attributed to the disease. It is calculated as follows: Proportional mortality rate of a disease = (No. of deaths due to that disease in the year/ Total no. 
of deaths in the year) *100. Option A: Case fatality rate measures the risk of persons dying from a certain disease within a 
given time period. It measures the killing power of a disease. It is used to link mortality to 
morbidity. Option B: Incidence measures the rate at which new cases are occurring in a population. It is not 
influenced by the duration of the disease. The use of incidence is generally restricted to acute 
diseases. Option C: Crude death rate is considered a fair indicator of the comparative health of the people. 
It is the rate of total deaths in a year compared to the mid-year population.

questions.question:
Question 7: You are researching the overall burden of COVID on a given population. Which of the 
following disability indicators is the best measure of this?
questions.explanation:
Disability adjusted life years (DALY) is the best measure of the overall burden of a disease in a 
defined population. It is also the best measure of the effectiveness of interventions. DALY is calculated as - Years of lost life prematurely (YLL) + Years lost to disability (YLD). It can 
measure both mortality and disability together. As DALY is affected by premature loss of life, conditions that affect younger individuals like road 
traffic accidents have a high DALY. In comparison to this, Alzheimer's disease has a lower DALY 
as it is a disease that mostly develops during old age and so has a lower YLL.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is not a health utilisation rate?

options.d: Average length of stay in hospital

questions.explanation:
Bed disability days is not a utilisation rate. It is an event-type disability indicator. It is defined as 
the number of days a person spent in a hospital bed due to illness or injury. Health utilisation rate is defined as the number of people making use of the available health 
services to the total number of individuals in that population. Health utilisation rates include: • Proportion of infants immunized against 9 diseases in the expanded program on immunization 
(EPI) • Proportion of women receiving antenatal care and supervised delivery • Percentage of population using family planning methods 35 
Sold by @itachibot • Bed occupancy rate • Average length of stay in the hospital • Bed turnover ratio

questions.question:
Question 9: As the medical superintendent of a hospital, you wish to optimise the utilization of health 
services. What bed turnover interval should you aim for?
questions.explanation:
For optimum utilization of health services in a hospital, bed turnover interval must always be 
slightly positive. Bed turnover interval is defined as the time interval where a hospital bed is 
left unoccupied following a patient’s discharge till the next patient occupies it after admission.

questions.question:
Question 10: Which of the following is the best indicator of availability, utilization, and effectiveness of 
health services?
questions.explanation:
Infant mortality rate (IMR) is the best indicator of the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of 
health care. It is a very sensitive indicator. Infant mortality rate (IMR)= Number of deaths in the first year of life/Number of live births x 
1000 It is also one of the best indicators of state failure. It is the most universally accepted health status 
indicator of the whole population and of the socio-economic status in which they live. Note: The best indicator of socio-economic development is the under-5 mortality rate.

questions.question:
Question 11: While reviewing a national health programme, you are asked to assess the cost-effectiveness 
of the interventions provided under it. Which indicator will you use to measure this?
questions.explanation:
QALY(Quality Adjusted Life Years) is used in assessing the cost-effectiveness (value of money) of a 
medical intervention. It is a measure of both the quality and quantity of life lived. It indicates the 
number of years of life that would be added by the intervention.

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following is not a socio-economic determinant of health? 29 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Lifestyle is a behavioural and socio-cultural determinant of health. It is not a socio-economic 
determinant. Socio-economic determinants of health are the following: • Economic status (per capita GNP) • Education • Occupation • Political system 36 
Sold by @itachibot Lifestyle is simply the way people live. It reflects our social values, attitudes, and activities. It is 
composed of: • Cultural patterns (daily nutrition, superstitions) • Behavioral patterns (personal hygiene, sedentary life) • Lifelong personal habits (e.g. smoking, alcoholism) Lifestyle is learned by social interaction with parents, siblings, friends, school, and mass media. Our political system determines our health. It can help shape community health services with 
regards to resource allocation, manpower policy, choice of technology, and the degree to which 
these services are made available & accessible to all segments of the society. The percentage of GDP spent on health is an indicator of political commitment. WHO 
recommends at least 5% of GDP to be spent on health care. India spends about 2.1 % of its GDP 
on health(budget 2022-23).

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is not a socio-economic indicator of health?
questions.explanation: Annual family income is not a socioeconomic indicator of health. Socio-economic indicators of health (mnemonic: H – FLAGGED): • Housing (number of persons per room) • Family size • Literacy rate (especially female literacy rate) • Availability of per capita calorie • GNP per capita • Growth rate of population • UnEmployment level • Dependency ratio

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following statements is false regarding positive health in today’s world?

options.a: It is dependent on social, economic, and cultural determinants
options.b: It is a mirage because of changing environment
options.c: It means that the body and mind are at peace
options.d: It includes provision of free health camps by the government

questions.explanation:
The provision of free health camps by the government is a concept of state medicine. Health does not merely mean the absence of disease or provision of diagnostic, curative, and 
preventive services. It is a state of physical, mental, and social well-being. The state of positive health is based on the idea of perfect functioning of the body and mind. 
According to this concept, health is: • Biologically a state in which every cell and organ in the body is functioning at optimum capacity • Psychologically a state in which the individual feels a sense of perfect well-being and mastery 
over his environment 37 
Sold by @itachibot • Socially a state in which the individual's capacities for participation in the social system are 
optimal This concept is too idealistic and can never become a reality. Humans can never be so perfectly 
adapted to the environment because everything in our life is subject to change. As the goal of positive health is unattainable, a broader concept of improving the quality of life 
has emerged. This highlights that positive health depends on medical action and also on 
economic, cultural, and social factors in the community.

questions.question: Question 15: As per the WHO, which of the following is not included in the standard of living?
questions.explanation:
Social security is a component of the level of living as per the United Nations and not standard of 
living. According to the WHO, the standard of living includes: • Income and occupation • Standards of housing, sanitation, and nutrition • Level of provision of health, educational, and recreational services It depends on per capita GNP.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following are components of the physical quality of life index (PQLI)?
questions.explanation:
Infant mortality rate, literacy rate, and life expectancy at 1 year of age are the components of the 
physical quality of life index (PQLI).

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is the best measure of the standard of living?
questions.explanation: Human development index (HDI) is the best measure of the standard of living of a population. Physical quality of life index (PQLI) measures the quality of life.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following is not a component of the human development index (HDI)?
questions.explanation:
Infant mortality rate (IMR) is not a component of HDI. It is a component of the physical quality of 
life index (PQLI). The human development index (HDI) is used to compare living standards in different countries. 
It includes the following dimensions or components: Each dimension index is calculated using the formula: Dimension Index = (Actual Value - 
Minimum Value)/(Maximum Value - Minimum Value) 38

questions.question:
Question 19: What are the minimum and maximum values established for the calculation of the life 
expectancy index in HDI?
questions.explanation:
The minimum value established for the calculation of the life expectancy index in HDI is 20 years 
and the maximum is 85 years. These minimum and maximum values are used to calculate the dimension indices in HDI and are 
called goalposts. Each dimension index is calculated using the formula: Dimension Index = (Actual Value - Minimum Value)/(Maximum Value - Minimum Value).

questions.question:
Question 20: Which of the following is not true regarding the education index used for calculating the 
HDI? 31 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: It includes expected years of schooling
options.c: Adult literacy rate is not considered
options.d: Minimum and maximum values are based on global data

questions.explanation:
The gross enrollment ratio is no longer used in obtaining the education index in HDI. It was used 
as an indicator earlier. The education index is calculated by taking into account the mean years of schooling and expected 
years of schooling. Maximum and minimum values are based on global data. Adult literacy rate and gross enrollment ratio were used as indicators before 2009.

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following is not included in the Ottawa charter for health promotion?

options.a: It implies that individual factors in the web have equal weightage
options.b: It implies that all the chains of causation must be controlled to prevent disease

questions.explanation:
Building social security is not included in the Ottawa charter for health promotion. The first international conference for health promotion was held in Ottawa on 21st Nov 1986. It 
produced a charter known as the Ottawa charter. The charter identified five key action areas as given below: • Build healthy public policy • Create supportive environment for health • Strengthen community action for health • Develop personal skills • Reorient health services 40
